intro: Ferocactus pilosus, commonly known as the hairy barrel cactus, is a species native to the arid regions of the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is characterized by its thick, ribbed stems that are covered in dense, white spines, which help to reduce water loss and provide protection from herbivores. The plant produces yellow flowers during the spring and summer, which are followed by red, fleshy fruits. Ferocactus pilosus is adapted to survive in extreme drought conditions, storing water in its succulent stems. Its unique morphology and ability to thrive in harsh environments make it a notable species in desert ecosystems.
